But after spending some time in the field, one of the things that we've concluded is,

Let's start off first with the core principles that we've seen be really consistent across product management.
Some of you may be familiar with this slide. It's a fairly common picture for representing how we think about product management.
What it tries to capture as product managers really at the intersection of a handful of different fields.
On the one hand, you are often the person representing the business interests. Whether it's on a feature basis or a team basis,
a big part of your responsibility is to say, "How is what we're doing makes sense for the business?" You also represent the technology side of things.
We'll sort of get into requirements for product managers and technical backgrounds in a minute, but one of the other pieces you have to do as a product manager consistently is say,
we represent the voice of technology, we're trying to build something new, we're trying to build something that has never been done before, is this possible?
Is it feasible or is it viable? On the last side, one of the other really core characteristics of a product managers,

Then a lot of research and development organizations, your responsibility is to be the primary voice of the customer inside that building.
You might have teams like Support or Sales that are talking to customers at different points in the product life cycle,

here is what we call the CEO versus the janitor. Some of you may have heard the phrase,
"The product manager is the CEO of the product." That part is definitely true,
what you may not have heard is, "The product manager is also the janitor of the product." What I mean by that is,
you are both responsible for things like high-level strategic vision and strategy settings for a product or for a set of features.
But you're also responsible for all the little things that fall through the cracks, whether it's figuring out
the latest set of bugs and doing prioritization process for them. Whether it's helping write text or copy

So it's pretty unique from a role perspective where you're both doing high-level work and low-level
work at the same time and you really have a high dynamic range which is pretty unique for a lot of roles in an industry.
The third thing that we've seen is a re-framing of the CEO and Janitor
piece that I found helpful and it's all about big picture to bugs and one of the things that was really interesting for me when I started my product management career was in the morning,

I mentioned this on the last slide, but one of the things that I think has been really powerful about the role and
a really good training ground for eventually becoming an executive is you're forced to figure out how to grapple with things both at

the reasons why we're obviously such big fans, especially early and mid-career, is you get exposure to a lot of
things and you would not normally get exposure to otherwise, and expands the full range all the way from
company strategy to literally what should the sentence be.
One of the other things we see is a very common pattern in product management is this concept of intra-team and inter-team communication.
This one is very much a function of companies sides but as companies get larger or as organizations get larger,
one of the persistent challenges they have is clear communication between different parts of the organization so that everybody is moving in the same direction.
I took a quick look at some of the companies list for people who are attending, some of you work at companies that are tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands,
or even potentially millions of people and one of the very persistent challenges in organizations of that size is how does the left hand,
knows what the right hand is doing. How you make sure that the teams are coordinated in communicating. A really key component of the product management job,

One bucket about communication within your team, so both defending your team from changes that can happen outside of it,
but also making sure that your team has the contexts that it needs to do good work. Then there's the inter-team communication.
How do you prevent two different teams from accidentally working on the same thing? Or if another team has a dependency on your team,

For friends who work at larger organizations, they might spend in excess of 75 percent of their time in

the product management function and I think of this as scaling, usually as organizations or companies get larger.
>> The next thing we wanted to talk about is influence without authority. This is another place where some of you may be familiar,
the Product Manager, it might be the CEO of the products, but usually in a reporting structure or in a chain of command hierarchy,

people that your strategy or your features or your documents are really correct.

The origins of product management were actually specifically to bring users into the research and development process.

We spend a lot of time talking to customers to really try and make sure that we have

The last thing that we really see as a commonality across a lot of the product management roles is what we call bringing the donuts.
This comes from a Ken Norman blog post, who was a Product Manager at Google for a number of years.
The concept that this really embodies is you are both a leader of your team, but you need to be a motivator of your team as well and it's

We say bringing the donuts because it's representative of keeping team morale or keeping team spirits high,

the common principles that exist across product management.
We differentiate between principles and responsibilities. The responsibilities are really what your job
is versus a set of things you need to think about. On responsibilities perspective, we began seeing
four really common patterns that exist across product management, agnostic of industry, agnostic on company size,
agnostic of all the other dimensions. The first one that we spend a lot of time talking about,
especially with more senior product managers, is this notion of setting a vision. This is something that you do
progressively more of as you get more senior in your career. But a big part of the product organization's purpose is to have
a vision and a strategy for where the company is going from a product perspective. What do we mean when we say vision and strategy?
What we mean when we say vision and strategy is there's a set of objectives that the company might want to
achieve or that the organization wants to achieve and a part of your job is to figure out how to get from where you are today,
to where you want to be. Really good product managers do this by setting goals instead of by setting paths.
What I mean by that is instead of telling people do this thing and do this thing, and then do this thing, you'll say,
"Today, we are here and we want to be here." You can harness the collective intelligence of
the organization to get from point A to point B. It's a lot about pushing decision making to the people who have context.
But if you can't set a clear goal for your organization and then let people apply their intelligence to figure out how to achieve that goal,
you will have an organization that is running in a number of different directions concurrently and it's very difficult for them to accomplish anything.
So this is really instrumental. Again, this is a thing you do more of as you progress through your product management career.
But setting a clear vision and a clear set of goals for an organization is an absolute must for any product manager.
The second thing that we really see as a common characteristic or a common responsibility across organizations and companies,
is managing a portfolio. Almost no product managers work on only one thing.
For those of you who have either worked with product managers or have some experience in the field, you're probably nodding your heads yes, when we bring this up.
Product managers seem to have their fingers on a lot of different products concurrently and your job is to manage a portfolio of things.
The reason your job is to manage a portfolio of things, is it's very difficult to accomplish a complex set of goals by doing only one thing.
So product managers need a very broad set of skills. You manage literal portfolios of projects from an R&D perspective,
but you might be doing a little bit of business development or a little bit of marketing or a little bit of sales or a little bit of PR.
You need to know enough in a bunch of different fields. It can be a bit dangerous and this portfolio management piece sort of
follows from the last concept of trying to achieve a goal. You have to have a robust set of skills that let you do many things concurrently.
Then you must make sure that all of the individual projects ladder up to more than some of the parts. That's really what portfolio management is about.
This ties into road mapping, which is not a concept that some people to be honest maybe familiar with. We can spend some time on later if people are curious.
But a road map is basically your plan for managing a portfolio of things. It's very much one of the core tools of a product manager.
The third responsibility that again, is very universal across all organizations,
is you have to actually get stuff done and you can have the best laid plans in the world. You can have the best road map in the world,
you can be an excellent communicator, but if you and your team are unable to actually get things done,
none of that really matters and a big part of your job is to bring things into existence that were not previously in existence.
It is a challenging execution problem. Project management is a sub-set of product management.
Product managers tend to do some project management, but also a bunch of other things. But is very much a core skill for getting things done.
Again, the core thesis here is, if you're not able to actually build stuff and turn something into reality,
the best laid plans don't matter at all, unless you can deliver it to the world and to your customers.
The last part of the product manager responsibility set is actually where we spend a lot of our time,
and it's called the product life cycle. The product life cycle is an industry and
an agnostic method of taking an individual idea from start to finish.
This is very much what we view as the heart of the product management discipline. You might have heard or seen product managers who work on features,
who work on products, whether they are new, whether existing. A core responsibility and skill is to take a single idea and
a single problem and take it all the way from idea to exist in the world.
We have a framework that Jioana and I have developed over a number of years,
that we think expressed this fairly well in an industry agnostic sense. The framework involves things like trying to figure out what problem you're solving.
Why it's actually important. It involves figuring out how to design elegant solutions to those problems.
It involves an execution piece, trying to actually building things to get stuff done. It is also a shipping piece that has to go to market components and PR components
and that recognizes that building is not enough people will not come. You need to figure out how to get your product into the hands of customers.
Involves a measurement component so that you can really close the loop on your hypotheses and figure out,
did you accomplish what you wanted to accomplish? The whole thing is iterated. This is sort of a variant of
the scientific method for those of you who are familiar with that as well. But this is very much where we spent a lot of
our time coaching and training the product managers. I think Pax may have mentioned this at the end, but we teach an entire online class on just the product life cycle concept.
For those of you who are interested, some opportunities to learn more in the comments.
But this is very much a core skill for product managers, and especially product managers in their career
